questions.question: "You're" and "your" are interchangeable contractions.
questions.explanation: "You're" is a contraction of "you are," while "your" is a possessive adjective, not a contraction.

questions.question: The contraction for "he will" is _______.
questions.explanation: "He’ll" is the standard contraction for "he will."

questions.question: "They _______ (are not) coming to the party."
questions.explanation: "Aren’t" is the correct contraction for "are not."

questions.question: "_______ (It has) been raining all day."
questions.explanation: "It’s" can be used as a contraction for both "it is" and "it has."

questions.question: "I'm" can be used as a contraction for both "I am" and "I have."
questions.explanation: "I’m" is only used as a contraction for "I am." For "I have," the contraction is "I’ve."

questions.question: "I _______ (have) been waiting for an hour."
questions.explanation: "I’ve" is the correct contraction for "I have" in this context.

questions.question: Which contraction represents "I would"?
questions.explanation: "I’d" is the correct contraction for "I would" (and also for "I had").

questions.question: What is the contraction for "does not"?
questions.explanation: "Doesn’t" is the correct contraction for "does not."

questions.question: "We _______ (would have) gone if we had known."
questions.explanation: "Would’ve" is the correct contraction for "would have."

questions.question: Which of these is a correct contraction for "we have"?
questions.explanation: "We’ve" is the correct contraction for "we have."

questions.question: Which contraction is formed from "could have"?
questions.explanation: "Could’ve" is the correct contraction for "could have."

questions.question: "They’re," "their," and "there" are all contractions.
questions.explanation: Only "they’re" (they are) is a contraction. "Their" is a possessive pronoun and "there" is an adverb.

questions.question: "She _______ (has not) finished her homework yet."
questions.explanation: "Hasn’t" is the correct contraction for "has not."

questions.question: Which contraction represents "who is"?
questions.explanation: "Who’s" is the correct contraction for "who is" (and also for "who has").

questions.question: "Isn’t" is a contraction of "is not."
questions.explanation: "Isn’t" is the correct contraction for "is not."

questions.question: "_______ (You have) got to be kidding me!"
questions.explanation: "You’ve" is the correct contraction for "you have."

questions.question: Which of these is a correct contraction for "should have"?
questions.explanation: "Should’ve" is the correct contraction for "should have."

questions.question: Which contraction is formed from "will not"?
questions.explanation: "Won’t" is the irregular contraction for "will not."

questions.question: What is the correct contraction for "you will"?
questions.explanation: "You’ll" is the correct contraction for "you will."

questions.question: Which of these is not a correct contraction?
questions.explanation: "Amn’t" is not a standard contraction in English. The phrase "am not" typically doesn’t have a contraction.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "We _______ been to Paris before, but we’re excited to go again."
questions.explanation: The correct contraction for "have" in this context is "’ve". The full sentence should read: "We’ve been to Paris before, but we’re excited to go again."

questions.question: Choose the correct contraction for the underlined words: "They are not coming to the party tonight."
questions.explanation: "They aren’t" is the correct contraction for "They are not." The sentence would become: "They aren’t coming to the party tonight."

questions.question: Which sentence uses contractions correctly?
options: Your going to love it when you see what I’ve bought.
You’re going to love it when you see what I’ve bought.
Your going to love it when you see what Ive bought.
You’re going to love it when you see what I’v bought.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses "You’re" (you are) and "I’ve" (I have).

questions.question: Which contraction is used incorrectly in this sentence? "It’s a beautiful day, and I think we’ll go for a walk, won’t we?"
questions.explanation: "It’s" (it is), "we’ll" (we will), and "won’t" (will not) are all used correctly in this sentence.

questions.question: Choose the correct contraction for the underlined words: "<u>She has not</u> finished her homework yet."
questions.explanation: "She hasn’t" is the correct contraction for "She has not." The sentence would become: "She hasn’t finished her homework yet."
